citation.article-title: Burkholderia ambifaria sp. nov., a novel member of the Burkholderia cepacia complex including biocontrol and cystic fibrosis-related isolates.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Burkholderia ambifaria sp. nov.

Burkholderia ambifaria (am.bi.fa'ria. M.L. adj. ambifarius that has two sides, of double meaning, ambiguous; referring to the fact that isolates of this species can be used for biological control purposes but also cause infections in humans)
Cells are Gram-negative, non-sporulating, straight rods.
All strains grow on MacConkey agar.
Oxidase, β-galactosidase and lysine decarboxylase activities are present.
No ornithine decarboxylase, tryptophanase, arginine dihydrolase or urease activity.
Positive for assimilation of glucose, L-arabinose, D-mannose, D-mannitol, N-acetylglucosamine, D-gluconate, caprate, adipate, L-malate, citrate and phenylacetate, but not maltose.
Positive for acidification of glucose, maltose, lactose, xylose and adonitol.

The small relative amounts of fatty acids 16:0 and 17:0 cyclo and the large relative amounts of summed feature 3 and summed feature 7 present in all strains investigated are good characteristics for identification (see Table 3).
Strains have been isolated from the environment and from the respiratory tract of CF patients.

The finding that this new taxon includes both strains isolated from CF patients and potentially useful biocontrol strains supports the general consensus that the large-scale use of biocontrol strains belonging to this taxon is ill-advised until more is known about their potential pathogenic mechanisms.
Phenotypic characteristics of the type strain are the same as those described above for the species.

In addition, the type strain is characterized by the presence of nitrate reduction, gelatinase activity, growth at 42 °C and acidification of sucrose and the absence of aesculin hydrolysis and pigment production.
Its G+­C content is 66.8 mol% and its 16S rDNA and recA gene sequences are available in GenBank under accession nos AF043302 and AF323985, respectively.
Strain LMG 19182T was isolated from the rhizosphere of pea plants in Wisconsin, USA, in 1985.
Strains LMG 19182T, LMG 6991, LMG 19465, LMG 19466, LMG 19467, LMG 11351, LMG 17828 and LMG 17829 have been deposited in the BCCM/LMG Bacteria Collection, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium.
